facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 486 and 487 of 1965 are appeals from judgments dated March 12, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 4308 of 1965 and 4309 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 486 and 487 of 1965. Appeals from the judgments dated the March 12, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 4308 of 1965 and 4309 of 1965.

facts.text: Kumaon Motorowners Union Limited was established in 1939 and had 330 members owning transport vehicles at the date of the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Kumaon Motorowners Union Limited  hereinafter referred to as the union  was established in 1939 and had at the date of the writ petitions. 330 members all of whom owned transport vehicles.

facts.text: Union members have public carrier permits and stage carriage permits valid up to various dates in 1966 and 1967 in Kumaon region except certain notified routes.

anchor.surface_text: These members have public carrier permits as well as stage carriage permits, which are in force in the Kumaon region except on certain numberified routes. The permits of the various members of the union are valid upto various dates falling in the years 1966 and 1967.

facts.text: On August 17, 1964, State Government issued notification prohibiting private operators from plying vehicles on Tanakpur-Dharchula route from October 1, 1964, under cls. (gg) and (i) of sub-rule (2) of r. 131 of Defence of India Rules, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On August 17, 1964, the State Government purporting to exer- cise powers under cls.  gg  and  i  of sub-rule  2  of r. 131 of the Defence of India Rules, 1962  hereinafter referred to as the Rules  issued a numberification by which it was directed that with effect from October 1, 1964, numberprivate operators shall ply any vehicle...

facts.text: Notification directed that only U.P. Government Roadways vehicles shall ply for carriage of persons and goods on Tanakpur-Dharchula route.

anchor.surface_text: It was further directed in the numberification that on this route, the U.P. Government Roadways vehicles alone shall ply for the carriage persons and goods. This result of this numberification was to stop plying of all vehicles belonging to the members of the union on, the route in question...

facts.text: Notification stopped plying of all vehicles belonging to union members on Tanakpur-Dharchula route, leading to filing of two writ petitions in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This result of this numberification was to stop plying of all vehicles belonging to the members of the union on, the route in question and this led to the filing of the two petitions in the High Court. The union was party to both the petitions...

facts.text: Petitioner challenged notification on grounds including lack of power under r.131(2)(gg) and (i), mala fides to circumvent Ch.IV-A of Motor Vehicles Act, contravention of s.44 of Defence of India Act, absence of necessary satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: In the petitions the appellants challenged the numberification of August 17, 1964, and this challenge was based on four grounds. In the first place, it was companytended that numberorder of the kind passed on August 17, 1964 companyld be passed under r. 131  2   gg  and  i . In the second place...

facts.text: State Government had considered nationalising Tanakpur-Dharchula route prior to August 1964 since 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In the second place, it was companytended that the U.P. Government was companytemplating nationalisation of this route in the Kumaon region for a long time prior to August 1964.

facts.text: Since 1960, reports from State Intelligence Department about anti-national and subversive elements infiltrating transport organisation, influencing drivers and private operators of the union.

anchor.surface_text: But the State Government justified the passing of the impugned order on the ground that since 1960 reports had started companying in from the State Intelligence Department that certain anti-national and subversive elements were infiltrating the transport Organisation...

facts.text: On October 1960, Deputy Commissioner, Almora sent report that no new routes in Pithoragarh should be given to union and operation limited to Almora proper for national security.

anchor.surface_text: As far back as October 1960, the Deputy Commissioner, Almora had sent a report to Government that it was necessary in the interest of national security that, numbernew routes in Pithoragarh should be given for operation to the union...

facts.text: On November 14, 1960, meeting of high officials decided to supply list of ring leaders, eliminate anti-national elements, screen employees, consider govt buses on border routes.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon in a meeting of high officials on November 14, 1960, it was decided that the Deputy Inspector General Intelligence, should supply the Transport Commissioner with a list of the ring leaders of such anti-national elements...

facts.text: Further meetings held in January and August 1961, noted difficulty eliminating undesirables due to labour laws, more reports of undesirable activities.

anchor.surface_text: Further meetings were held in January and August 1961 in which it was pointed out that it was difficult to eliminate undesirable elements from transport organizations on account of existing labour laws.

facts.text: In May 1962, tentatively decided to operate transport in border areas by Government alone.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in May 1962, it was tentatively decided by the State Government that the real solution to the problem lay in the operation of transport in the border areas by Government alone.

facts.text: Chinese attacked in October 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This was the, situation when the Chinese attacked in October 1962.

facts.text: In November 1962, an employee of the union detained under r.30(1)(b) of Rules for prejudicial activities.

anchor.surface_text: In November 1962, an employee of the union had to be detained under r. 30  1   b  of the Rules as his activities were companysidered prejudicial to the defence of India and public safety.

facts.text: In October 1963, impressed on Transport Commissioner to eliminate anti-national elements from border transport organisations.

anchor.surface_text: The matter remained under companysideration for another year and in, October 1963 it was again impressed on the Transport Commissioner to eliminate anti-national elements from the transport organisations...

facts.text: In January 1964, transport department reported nationalisation would not be economical.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1964 it appears that the transport department reported that nationalisation would number be economical and that the Government would stand to lose if it eliminated all private operators...

facts.text: Chief Minister finally decided in July 1964 to take route from private operators for security, leading to notification on August 17, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, it was finally decided in August 1964 after the matter was put up before the Chief Minister who dealt with matters arising out of the Act and the Rules that in the interest of security... It was in companysequence of this decision of the Chief Minister finally made in July 1964...

facts.text: High Court negatived all contentions of appellants and dismissed petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived all the companytentions raised on behalf of the appellants. As to the satisfaction of the Chief Minister before the issue of the impugned order... the petitions were dismissed.

facts.text: Appellants obtained certificates from High Court and appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then obtained certificates from the High Court and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds impugned order within powers under r.131(2)(gg) and (i).

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the order passed by the State Government on August 17, 1964 was within its powers under r., 131  2   gg  and  i  of the Rules.

facts.text: No mala fides in the order, not a device to avoid compensation under Ch.IV-A.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that there is numberquestion of the order being mala fide or having been passed as a device to avoid payment of companypensation under Ch. IV-A of the Motor Vehicles Act.

facts.text: Order does not contravene s.44 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are number prepared to hold that the order in question interferes with the rights of the appellants more than was necessary for the purpose to be attained.

facts.text: Necessary satisfaction of State Government existed before issuing order, as per affidavit filed August 16, 1965 by Deputy Secretary, Home Dept.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence an affidavit was filed on behalf of the State Government on August 16, 1965 by the Deputy Secretary  Home Department  U.P. Government, Lucknow.

facts.text: Chief Minister considered matter on December 5, 1963 or so and July 30, 1964, decided to take over route for security.

anchor.surface_text: It was further stated that after various meetings of the officials of the State, the matter was put up before The Chief Minister on December 5, 1963 or so... eventually on July 30, 1964, it was finally decided by the Chief Minister...

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are hereby dismissed.

CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 486 and 487 of 1965. Appeals from the judgments dated the March 12, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 4308 of 1965 and 4309 of 1965.

issues.text: Whether the impugned order of August 17, 1964 is beyond the power of the State Government under cls. (gg) and (i) of sub-rule (2) of r. 131 of the Defence of India Rules?

anchor.surface_text: We shall first companysider the companytention that the impugned order is beyond the power of the State Government under r. 131 2  gg  and  i . Rule 131 provides for companytrol of road and water transport.

issues.text: Whether cl. (gg) of r. 131(2) empowers prohibition of private operators from plying vehicles on a particular route?

anchor.surface_text: The first companytention on behalf of the appellants is that r. 131  2   gg  must be read in the companytext of companytrol of road transport and so read it only gives power to the State Government to companytrol the use of vehicles and does number empower it to prohibit private operators from plying vehicles on any particular route with respect to which the order may be made.

issues.text: Whether s. 43 of the Defence of India Act prevails over s. 68B of the Motor Vehicles Act and Ch. IV-A provisions requiring compensation?

anchor.surface_text: This argument is met on behalf of the State by reference to S. 43 of the Act which lays down that the provisions of this Act or any rule made thereunder or any order made under any such rule shall have effect numberwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith companytained in any enactment other than this Act...

issues.text: Whether the impugned order destroys the commercial undertaking of the appellants?

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that by passing the impugned order, the companymercial undertaking of the union is destroyed, and that this companyld number be the intention behind cl.  gg  of r. 1 3 1  2  of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it is urged that in any case the second part of the order which directs that the Roadways Vehicles will only ply for carriage of persons and goods on the route in question cannot fall under cl.  1  of r. 131 2 .

issues.text: Whether the impugned order was mala fide or passed as a device to circumvent Ch. IV-A of the Motor Vehicles Act and avoid compensation?

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the question of mala fides. The argument is that the order was passed under r. 131  2   gg  in order to avoid payment of companypensation by taking action under Ch. IV-A of the Motor Vehicles Act.

issues.text: Whether the impugned order contravenes s. 44 of the Defence of India Act by interfering more than necessary with avocations and property?

anchor.surface_text: Then we companye to the argument that the action taken was more, than the situation demanded and therefore under s. 44 of the Act the order was vitiated.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the last point that has been urged on behalf of the appellants, namely, that it was number proved that the State Government was satisfied that it was necessary and expedient...

holdings.text: The order passed by the State Government on August 17, 1964 was within its powers under r. 131(2)(gg) and (i) of the Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the order passed by the State Government on August 17, 1964 was within its powers under r., 131  2   gg  and  i  of the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.(gg) empowers prohibition/restriction on persons plying vehicles as vehicles are inanimate; cl.(i) complementary to fill vacuum with govt vehicles; s.43 DIA overrides MVA Ch.IV-A; no destruction of undertaking.

holdings.text: s. 43 of the Defence of India Act must prevail over s.68B of the Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that s. 43 of the Act must prevail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: DIA later than MVA; emergency legislation; more emphatic non-obstante clause; s.64 only amends specified MVA provisions, does not incorporate entire Act.

holdings.text: There is no destruction of the commercial undertaking of the union.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that in this case there is no destruction of the commercial undertaking of the union, for the simple reason that it is not disputed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order prohibits only on one route, not all; no takeover of assets; profit capacity reduced but undertaking intact.

holdings.text: The second part of the order directing U.P. Government Roadways vehicles to ply falls under cl.(i) of r.131(2).

anchor.surface_text: That clause in a sense is complementary to the provisions of other clauses of r. 131 2 . Where the State Government decides to issue a prohibition under cl.  gg , it must naturally provide for alternative methods

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.(i) allows other provisions to secure defence etc., including filling vacuum created by prohibition under cl.(gg) with govt vehicles.

holdings.text: There is no question of the order being mala fide or having been passed as a device to avoid payment of compensation under Ch. IV-A of the Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that there is no question of the order being mala fide or having been passed as a device to avoid payment of compensation under Ch. IV-A of the Motor Vehicles Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Security concerns since 1960, intensified post-1962 Chinese aggression; 4 years deliberation explored alternatives; affidavit averments credible.

holdings.text: The order in question does not interfere with the rights of the appellants more than was necessary.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are not prepared to hold that the order in question interferes with the rights of the appellants more than was necessary for the purpose to be attained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioners failed to show lesser measure suffices; govt attempted other ways over years before prohibiting.

holdings.text: The necessary satisfaction of the State Government was there before the impugned order was issued.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this affidavit filed in this Court there can be no doubt that the necessary satisfaction of the State Government which is a condition precedent for the issue of an order under the rules was there before the impugned order was issued.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit details Chief Minister's consideration on Dec 5, 1963 and final decision July 30, 1964 after deliberations.
